snippet: The pope’s remarks stirred up divisions in the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church in South America about whether birth control should be widely allowed.
abstract: Pope Francis condones use of contraceptives in predominantly Roman Catholic Latin American countries suffering from Zika virus; makes endorsement, which could shift governmental positions on practice, in hopes of lowering number of babies born with severe birth defects associated with virus.

byline.original: By SIMON ROMERO and JIM YARDLEY
byline.contributor: Simon Romero reported from São Paulo, and Jim Yardley from aboard Pope Francis’ plane. Reporting was contributed by Jonathan Gilbert from Buenos Aires; Vinod Sreeharsha from Rio de Janeiro; Susan Abad from Bogotá, Colombia; Azam Ahmed from Mexico City; and Gene Palumbo from San Salvador.

lead_paragraph: The pope’s remarks stirred up divisions in the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church in South America about whether birth control should be widely allowed.

headline.main: Francis Says Contraception Can Be Used to Slow Zika
headline.print_headline: Francis Says Contraception Can Be Used to Slow Zika
